clean_story:
Quick judgments. Memory shortcuts.

The availability heuristic is a mental trick where your brain guesses what’s likely based on what’s easiest to remember.

Like picking a snack from the front of the fridge instead of digging for the hidden one.

If shark attacks flood the news, you might fear swimming—even though drowning is 3,000x more likely.

Your brain mistakes easy-to-recall for common.

Example: After a plane crash, more people buy flight insurance—though crashes are rarer than car accidents.

Or assuming all dogs bite because one growled at you.

This shortcut saves time but distorts risks.

Advertisers exploit it: "9 out of 10 dentists!" (But how many were asked?)

To outsmart it, ask: "Is this easy to remember because it’s true—or just loud?"

Cognitive biases.

Risk perception.

How memory shapes decisions.
